participants.participant: Warwick Bryan, Executive General Manager, Investor Relations
Ralph Norris, Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for coming this morning, and welcome to today's presentation of Commonwealth Bank of Australia's Result for the Year Ended 30 June, 2010.

Today's presentation will follow our normal process, which Ralph will kick-off and talk about the overview and the general themes. David will then talk in more detail about the results. So, after that we will have an opportunity for questions.
So I'll hand over to Ralph. Thank you very much.
Thanks very much, Warwick, and good morning to you all.

The Commonwealth Bank has today reported another good operating result, which is testament to the significant progress we've made over the last four years in executing our key strategic priorities. The result was delivered in a challenging environment, particularly in the second half as credit growth and business momentum slowed.

While I remain confident about the medium to long-term outlook for the Australian economy, recent uncertainty over the pace of recovery in the United States and Europe highlight the downside risks at play, and have not helped domestic consumer and business confidence.

As a result, it's appropriate to maintain a degree of caution about the short-term prospects, and we have therefore retained our conservative capital and liquidity savings. However, I remain optimistic about the strength of the Group's business franchise and our ability to continue to deliver superior returns for our shareholders.

Turning now to the result itself, cash net profit after-tax was up 42% to $6.1 billion, statutory net profit after-tax was up 20% to almost $5.7 billion, and David Craig in his presentation will provide the reconciliation between the cash and statutory profit numbers. Return on equity rebounded strongly to a healthy 18.7%, and cash earnings per share was up 34% to $3.96. This was a strong result built on good volume growth and continuing cost discipline.

Again, all of our businesses performed well, which is particularly pleasing and a testimony to a consistent, clearly defined and well-executed strategy, which the team has put in place over the last four years. Relative to position 12 months ago, the result also benefited from a reduction in impairment expense as worst of the bad debt cycle appears to have passed, and improving equity markets which drove a strong turnaround and investment experience in this period.

We delivered for shareholders by raising the final dividend by $0.55 to $1.70, an increase of 48%. This lifted total dividends for the financial year to $2.90, returning the payout ratio to pre-GFC levels of 74%. Given the Group's high level of Tier 1 capital, the directors have decided to remove the previous dividend reinvestment plan discount of 1.5%, and neutralize or minimize the dilutive effect of the dividend reinvestment plan through an on-market share purchase.

Since early 2006, the Commonwealth Bank has consistently pursued a simple, clear strategic plan with the objective of becoming Australia's finest financial services organization through excelling in customer service.

Once again, today's good financial result is testimony to the successful execution of this strategy. As I indicated at the half year results, the Group has made significant progress over the past four years across our five core strategic priorities. And I don't intend to dwell on each of these strategies today, but I'd like to focus on one area, which has been the subject of some commentary of late, and that is the area of small business.

Unfortunately, much of this commentary has been, I believe, rather ill-informed. When I joined the Group some five years ago, we said about improving the Group's historically underweight position in business banking. Far from ignoring this area, as some have indicated, this has been one of the Group's five strategic goals, and I'm pleased to say that over the past four years, we have made significant progress.

From an underweight position, we now have the highest or close to highest market shares in both business lending and business deposits in the country. Over the past four years, we've opened new business banking centers, we've deployed more local business bankers, put business bankers back into branches, rolled out our market leading business banking platform compass, and made a number of other enhancements to our products, systems and processes to improve business customer experience.

At all times we've remained open for business, and have been ready, willing and able to support our customers. Indeed over the past six months, at a time when all of the other major banks have experienced declining balances, we have been growing our business lending balances and gaining market share.

In SME lending, we are growing our balances at an annualized rate of 7%, well ahead of system growth. In business banking, our customer satisfaction score as measured by TNS has improved from 56.5% to just under 68%, and we have shown the fastest rate of improvement amongst the major banks. Further reinforcing the progress we've made, the recent DBM Business Financial Services Monitor survey recognized the Group as the number one major bank across all big business segments.

More generally on customer satisfaction, we've come from a position of being a clear last to now showing consistent improvement across every segment of our business. And this year, it was particularly pleasing to have again being rewarded with the accolade of 2010 Money magazine Bank of the Year award.

In the year ahead, we will concentrate on the momentum we've achieved in business banking, and continue our relentless focus on customer satisfaction underpinned by the roll-out of our core banking modernization program.

This slide shows some of the many initiatives we've undertaken to help our customers and improve customer satisfaction. As you can see, improvements in customer satisfaction are translating directly into better cross-sell performance and more products to the customer.

As we improved our customer satisfaction levels, we are finding that our 11 million domestic customers are increasingly willing to do more of their business with us, to the point where we now have the highest number of products per customer of the major banks.

Given the size of our customer base, this translates directly into stronger revenue growth. It's also worth pointing out that within our total of 2.56 products per customer, we have the highest rate of deposit product ownership amongst the major banks. While we have made real progress, there is still significant opportunities for us to further improve our customer satisfaction and cross-sell outcomes. Core banking modernization is the next key phase in the evolution of our strategy, something which will further enhance customer experience and deliver a clear and distinct strategic advantage over coming years.

The program is tracking to plan and producing some encouraging early results. The first key phase, the migration of over 1 million term deposits from our legacy Hogan package has been completed successfully, and we remain on track to migrate our remaining deposit products and transaction accounts by year-end.

The Bankwest acquisition has been a very good one for the CBA. Integration work has proceeded smoothly, and Bankwest operating performance remains very strong, highlighted by growing customer numbers, improving customer satisfaction, strong income growth and significant improvements in cost to income ratio.

At the time we acquired Bankwest, we were aware that while the West Coast retail franchise was of a high quality, there were likely to be credit quality issues within the business banking book, as a result of the aggressive growth strategy previously issued by Bankwest under HBOS ownership.

Once we acquired Bankwest, we quickly introduced substantial improvements to lending practices and risk management procedures, and conducted a comprehensive review of the high-risk elements of the book, which we identified as being predominantly on the East Coast.

Following a disappointing loan impairment experience in the March quarter, a detailed review was initiated, focused primarily on the performing component of the legacy Bankwest business book, and the results of this review were then extrapolated to the remaining lower risk segment of the book.

This comprehensive review conducted in conjunction with external industry advisors has identified systemic issues in the portfolio, which led to risk rate reassessments and security revaluations, resulting in the recognition of a 212 million after-tax loan impairment expense to pre-acquisition loans. It's important to note that these problems relate to smaller performing loans that were written prior to CBA's acquisition of Bankwest.

Finally, before turning to the outlook, I wanted to talk about a few broader issues. Not only has 2010 been a good year for the Group and shareholders, but has also delivered great outcomes for all the stakeholders. What this slide shows is that our shareholders are only one of a number of groups who share in the $18 billion of revenue, which we generate each year.

As an organization, we employee over 45,000 people, and in a period where many global banks have been reducing head count, we actually increased the number of employees in the 2010 year as we've grown our business.

Last year, we paid out people over $4.5 billion, which help support families and communities right across Australia. At the same time, we remain committed to retaining jobs within Australia, and are not currently undertaking or planning to undertake any offshoring. Much of the $4 billion of expenses shown on this slide was paid to many thousands of external third-party suppliers for a wide range of products and services. All of these companies received competitive remuneration and provided employment to thousands of Australians and contribute directly to the economy.

We are re-investing in the business to ensure that it remains strong and has the ability to continue to grow profitably. We also paid over $2.9 billion on taxes in the 2010 financial year. And finally, our 780,000 shareholders have benefited from the Group's robust performance and financial resilience. With the Group paying out 74% of its profits, they will receive $4.5 billion in dividends for this financial year, and most of that will go directly to moms and dads, or indirectly to millions of Australians via the superannuation funds.

Our customers tell us that we are providing them with better service and they're rewarding us by doing more of their business with us. In addition, in the current year, we've reduced exception and ATM usage fees to our retail and business customers by over $200 million. And while consumers in many countries are finding it difficult to get credit, we continue to support our customers with over $100 billion of new loans and advances, most of which were to our retail and small business customers.

As I've noted before, robust banking systems are the cornerstone of a strong economy. So in part, the relatively good performance of the Australian economy over the past two years can be attributed to the strength of our banking system. In fact, it is our continued strong performance that has enabled us to remain one of only a handful of global banks to still have a AA credit rating. Without that rating, it would have been much more difficult and significantly more expensive for us to raise funds in wholesale markets, which would have in turn made supporting our customers much more challenging.

Now turning to the outlook. Despite some improvement, the global recovery remains uneven with concerns about the advanced economies balanced out by strength in the emerging economies. However, the Australian economy remains well placed relative to most other developed countries. Pleasingly, some of the uncertainty over capital and liquidity requirements for the industry, which has persisted for some time has diminished, thanks to the collaborative efforts of the banks and the regulators over the past 18 months. Recent uncertainty over the pace of recovery in the United States and Europe highlight the downside global economic risks still in play. These risks have not helped domestic business and consumer confidence, both of which remain fragile.

This fragility manifests itself in slowing – in the slowing and the underlying momentum of our business at the end of the 2010 financial year. As a result, it is appropriate to maintain a degree of caution about the prospects for our business for the coming year, and we intend to retain conservative capital and liquidity settings for the foreseeable future, so that we are able to provide support to our customers in what are uncertain times. Despite the current economic headwinds, I'm optimistic about the medium term outlook for Australia and the Group's ability to deliver superior returns for our shareholders.
Thank you. And I'll now hand over to David Craig to run you through the results in greater detail. Thank you. David?
Well, good morning everybody. It's nice to be able to talk another good result to you.

Analysts and investors have been asking me a number of particular questions of late focusing on some very specific issues. And so I'm going to try to cover those in this presentation. Now in so doing and in keeping the presentation to a manageable length, some of the favorite slides that you've probably seen in the past have been relegated to the back of the pack or included in other material. But I'm sure that in the 311 pages of material we've released to you today, all of your questions are going to be answered.

So turning to the result, as Ralph has pointed out, a $6.1 billion cash net profit after-tax was up 42%. At a headline level, our revenue for the year is up 6% and expenses up 5, giving a positive jaws, and an operating performance up 8. However, in the second half of the year, there has been some slowing in revenue and negative jaws and I will explain that a little later on.

You'll also notice that the result has benefited from a turnaround in investment experience, which went from negative 263 million last year to positive 236 million, with the improvement in equity markets, and of course, a significantly lower impairment expense.

If we have a look at the statutory profit compared to the cash net profit after-tax, you will see two significant items that are classified below the line. The first one, the New Zealand conduit tax settlement, which was reported in the first half of the year, and the second one being $216 million of non-cash items on Bankwest, primarily being as Ralph has pointed out, the result of the detailed review we did on performing loans, pre-acquisition performing loans in the Bankwest book, which proved to be far less well provided for than we expected, and we've adjusted that effectively against the $614 million acquisition profit that we declared last year. The other non-cash items are pretty much consistent with prior year's.

If we have a look at each of the business units, it's pleasing to see that really across the board we've had strong underlying operating profit growth. In the case of the retail bank, a further 15% growth in operating revenue with 9% banking income growth and costs is flat. Volume is a key driver in the banking result across the board, and I'm going to go through that in more detail in a moment. In institutional banking and markets, income was up 7%, margins improved, and importantly, our cash net profit after-tax was up over $1 billion, of course, with the release of impairment or reversal of impairment problems.

At the same time, expenses in that business were up 17%, as a reflection of the fact that it's a far more profitable business, and so there were higher compensation paid to the employees in that area, and as well as that we've been investing in parts of our business.

In Business and Private Banking, it's really pleasing to see double-digit growth in every single one of the businesses there, income up 11% and costs up 3. As Ralph has pointed out, Bankwest income was up 25 and costs down 3, and that's driven our cost to income ratio in that business, down from 66% a year ago to now 51%.
In Wealth Management, again, pleasing to see increase in funds under administration, and improving markets have led to income up 5, and costs again under control, up just 1.

And then finally in New Zealand, the recession there is finally abiding but there are some one-offs that make that results look the way it does. The year before last, we had break fees that – fees paid to the bank by customers going from fixed rate loans to variable rate loans, and they were 100 million higher in the corresponding previous period, and trading income declined on the back of lower volatility.

Really the headline story in this result is about volume. As Ralph has said, a drive on customer satisfaction and competitive pricing has seen volume greater than system in every one of our major products. Our home lending and business lending both up well. Deposits in both household and business growing greater than system. And funds under administration growing ahead of system. What's particularly pleasing to see here is that with business lending in the system declining 3.7, our business lending grew 3.3. And specifically, within that, our SME lending actually grew at 7%.

Those volume growth numbers have really driven the operating result. As you can see, $919 million added to our operating income for the year through volume, offset to some degree by the 219 million impact of reductions in exception fees and other fees, particularly in the retail bank. You will see that our trading income for the year is pretty much flat period – each six month period, settling between 290 and $310 million, and funds and insurance income is just steadily increasing.

The other side of the ledger from the volume, though, is the price, and there is no doubt that our funding costs have continued to increase. The left-hand diagram here shows the yield curve or the cost of raising funds just before the recession and what that yield curve looked like at the 30th of June, 2010. And as you can see, a very significant increase as we roll off low interest, pre-GFC debt for much higher cost debt now, it's increasing our funding costs. And that you can see in the right-hand diagram under the Wholesale Funding where since the beginning of the GFC, our wholesale funding costs have increased 89 basis points.

Significantly, though, this has also impacted consumer deposits with a great deal of competition in this market from regional banks and, of course, from the Big Four. And in the deposits space, our cost of funds has increased 146 basis points, so when you count the fact that that 58% of our funding comes from that retail deposit market or consumer deposit market, our increased funding costs since the beginning of the GFC is 122 basis points.

This chart shows you our net interest margin in six monthly periods since the beginning of the GFC, starting with the decline that was caused by the original turbulence, the higher funding costs, which were not immediately passed on to our customers, and then the repricing that occurred to take account of the much higher risk that hadn't been properly factored into pricing, as well as those higher funding costs, which peaked early in the first half of this year. But since then, net interest margin has been under pressure from continuingly higher funding costs, which has driven net interest margin down 10 basis points in the second half.

You can see this more specifically when you look at the retail bank. Pre-GFC, we had a margin in that area of 251 basis points, which had declined to 226 by the beginning of this year. It picked up early on in this year, as we had an out-of-cycle rate rise of 10 basis points in June that flowed through in the first half. But in the second half, as you can see, 24 basis points of incremental funding on the retail book, which is only being very partially recovered in pricing. And so margins in the retail bank are down 14 basis points in the second half.

It's been these higher funding costs then that have driven our negative operating income in the second half. As you can see, there are three fewer working days in the second half, and that's accounted for about 1% of decline or 98 million. And the fee changes that occurred in the first half have had a compound effect in the second half, knocking a further 47 million off. But it has been the $280 million decline on margins or 3% that has really told the story in the second half result on income.

On the other hand, looking at the other side of the ledger on costs, you are aware that in the first half, we were able to contain our cost growth to just 1%, and I am pleased to say that in the second half, that's been further contained to just a further 1.5%, with most of that being related to IT expense, maintenance, development, and just significantly higher volumes going through the business that lead to higher IT costs.

However, and very pleasingly from my point of view, throughout this period and for the third successive year, we have invested more than $1 billion in our business. We're determined to get this business right and to set it up perfectly for the future. Of course, core banking modernization that Ralph was talking about is a very substantial portion of that investment spend.

Turning now to impairment, and what you can see here is impairment expense running pretty much as we predicted. That is, in December '08 we had the spike from institutional banking when the GSC first hit.

That then tailed off through SME and consumer lending, which in the case of CBA, we voluntarily passed the peak of, but it has a longer lag on it. But unfortunately, Bankwest has continued to have problems in its legacy book, and that has been a cost to this year. On the right-hand side, you can see that in the second half of the year, we've expensed $441 million of impairment for Bankwest and 251 million for the rest of the CBA Group.

However, we have continued to maintain strong and conservative balance sheet provisioning. With the total provisioning sitting pretty much same level as it was at December, the management overlay has reduced slightly but it's still very strong at $1.2 billion.

Now, the reason for that reduction in management overlay is purely an improvement in credit in the CBA book. So as the quality of the underlying loans improves, the collected provision declines and the management overlay relating to that collected provision declines, and that's what you're seeing flowing through there.

You can see what I was talking about on the consumer bank on the right-hand side with consumer arrears across the board, declining, and they're declining also in New Zealand, which is not specifically shown there.

Looking at impaired assets, you can see that in this current period new impaired assets are 46 billion, down from the 51 and 49 of the prior two periods. So there is a tailing off going on in most – a big chunk of that 46 billion, of course – 46 basis points, I'm sorry, is Bankwest.

The total impaired at 102 is up, but, of course, you're going to see that continue to rise slightly, because once loans get into that impaired bucket it takes a long while to work through insolvency or whatever, and so it will be awhile before that tails down.

Now another question that I have been asked about a lot is funding, and in particular funding for Australia, and there is no doubt that at the moment we are facing a long-term issue as a country. Our credit growth in this country is greater than our deposit growth, because we're growing in strong economy. And so that means that our funding task is greater than the domestic capacity to fund us. We have to fund offshore, and of course, we know that our global funding costs are increasing significantly, and they're going to continue to increase, in part because of the volatility overseas, in part because international banks are now starting to lend. And so if they're going to start to lend, they'll start to borrow in their own markets; and in part because the regulation internationally is causing those banks to have to hold more liquid assets and to term out their debt. So the competition for international long-term debt is tough, and that will keep rates internationally high.

On the other hand, looking at the impact of regulation locally, as Ralph has said, I think there has been some very good work done, and while we're not through the entire regulatory thing, it's clear that in Australia we will be able to manage that regulation, although overtime we will certainly have to continue building up our liquid assets, and that means that we'll have to continue funding more.

In Australia, rather uniquely, home loans, all of our home loans are on bank balance sheets. Now that's quite different to what other financial systems have. We don't have the active securitization markets with some of the other methods of taking home loans off balance sheet but other countries do, and so our balance sheets do look different.

But Australia itself as a country remains an extremely attractive investment proposition where a strong fast-growing economy tapped into Asia, and we're going to as a country continue to attract both equity and debt investment. It's just a question of how that will come through.

In the meantime, the Australian banks are very well regarded internationally. CBA like its peers has had a step change in funding costs, but our excess to debt markets internationally and locally remains extremely strong. We are very well regarded internationally, and as you know we've retained our AA stable rating.

We continue to mange our treasury operations in a prudent manner, which means that we strive to have as diversified a funding profile as we can. We are continuing to extend our term maturity and we are pre-funding to ensure that when there is a volatility, let there was, for example, in the last quarter, we don't have to go out and fund that, the most ridiculously high rates. At year-end we got about $14 billion pre-funded towards this current year. And particularly we are working very collaboratively with the ABA, with Treasury and with regulators on these systemic issues for Australia, and I am confident that they will be addressed appropriately.

Let's turn then to the funding and what's happened for the year. Well, what this chart shows you is a few things. Firstly, that almost all of our funding needed to fund our asset growth came from deposits this year, $26 billion of additional deposits. Wholesale funding, in fact, in aggregate only accounted for $3 billion of our funding. However, what you can see under there is a significant shift from short-term wholesale funding into long-term.

Now this is a prudent measure to ensure that we have long stable funding but it comes as a significant cost, and you can see from the graph below the bars that we are effectively replacing cheap old short-term debt with much more expensive long-term debt and that carries with it the cost.

If we look at what's happened to funding as a whole, our new funding this year was at an average tenure of five years, and that's increased our total long-term debt tenure to 3.8 years, up from 3.6 years at the beginning of this year. At the same time, retail deposit or consumer deposits now account for 58% of our total funding, up from 56%, and we're keeping – increasing our liquid asset holdings.

Tier 1 Capital organically has continued to grow, and you can see that we were looking at upwards of 9.52% of capital before considering this on market purchase. From our point of view, we don't need that much capital, and so we are – as Ralph has pointed out, taking the discount off our DRP and we will conduct an on market buyback to neutralize the DRP and bring our capital back to 9.15%, which we still regard as extremely strong and conservative. Our Tier 1 ratio has increased from 8.07 to 9.15, and on a U.K. FSO basis that's equivalent to 12.82%.

So let me summarize for you. It's been another good financial result; with cash net profit after tax at 6.1 billion, up 42%. Our return on equity for this year is 18.7%. This is being driven by very strong volume growth with all our major products performing ahead of system. However, the headwind has been in margin, with margins down 10 basis points in the second half. In the face of this, we've been keeping our costs very tightly under control, with costs in the second half only increasing 1.5%, but at the same time we'd continue to invest in our business with a further $1 billion invested in the current year.

As Ralph has said, we are maintaining our very conservative settings with $1.2 billion of management overlay in our provisioning with a Tier 1 ratio of close to 9.2% and $14 billion of pre-funding on our debt profile. Above all though, it's been our clear and focused strategy, our focus on those five key initiatives, and in particular, continuing focus on improving our customer satisfaction, that is driving these volume increases and delivering the great result.
Ralph and I would now like to take any questions you may have.

Thanks, David. Just before we kick-off, just a couple of ground rules. Can you please wait for the microphone and also identify yourself, and if you could just limit yourself to two questions initially. I understand there is some media on the line, appreciate if they could keep their questions till the media briefing this afternoon. And I'll start questions from the floor and then I'll move to the phone.
So Jon, Jon Mott?

Yeah, hi guys, Jon Mott from UBS. Just a question, some of the issues that you talked about there, a strong credit growth in the second half, but obviously the margin got hit and with the funding cost obviously going up. Are we now at this stage where the marginal cost of funding is almost equal to the marginal revenue you're getting on these loans that you're writing at the moment? And is it actually, are we now in a situation that unless we re-price, we're now seeing profitless growth across the banking sector? And if that's the case, should the banks just keep lending over, what's the outlook for the return on assets going forward?

Well, I don't think, Jonathan, we've reached that point yet that the marginal cost for – on a loan from the point of view of funding cost has reached the point where its profitless business. But certainly over the second half, we did see a diminution in margin of 10 basis points, but margin was still overall at around 2.08%.
Thank you. Victor German from Nomura. Just a question on bad debts.

I understand the rationale that you've outlined with relation to Bankwest, but are you able to, first of all, make assurance that we should not expect further deterioration in that book and further below the line adjustments? And also, if you actually experience, what you experienced in that book improves going forward, should we expect write-backs to be below the line as well?

I think it's fair to say that we will treat the write-backs consistently in regard to those particular – that particular portfolio of loans that we have gone through without operation Magellan to establish where the weaknesses were in that portfolio. You will notice that there were significant bad debt expense above the line in regard to Bankwest, but this was primarily due to the fact that that particular book of loans, which are all currently performing was the fact that we were concerned during the third quarter that we saw a number of loans that came straight from the loan book without going through a watchlist to being impaired. And as a result of that, we decided to undertake obviously a very rigorous review of that portfolio, and came to the conclusion that based on Commonwealth Bank writings, they are about one and a half writing levels higher than that would be on the Commonwealth Bank book.

At the same time, we also looked at the collateral supporting those loans, and came to the conclusion with expert advice that the valuations in regard to that collateral were also inflated. And as a result of that, we came to the conclusion that we would take that write-off below the line against the pre-acquisition profit that we booked last year below the line because if we had obviously established that in the first half of last year, we would have netted that off at the – against the pre-acquisition profit, so that's the rationale.

James Freeman from Deutsche Bank. I just want to actually ask a bit on the margin inside. You've mentioned some housing – sorry – you've shown your retail books had a bit of contraction in the margin in the second half. Just a view on an out-of-cycle rate rise I know you need there?

And second question is just actually, having a look at your outlook statement, you are saying that the business has slowed or the momentum has slowed towards the end of the financial year in '11. Just a bit of a view as to where you expect that to go? I notice your credit forecast is still relatively high at about 9.5%?

Yes, sure, James. I think the issue here in regard to out-of-cycle increases, we haven't made any decision in regard to that situation. All I'll say is that we've worked very hard over the period of the last two and a half years, as the global financial crisis has obviously wound its way through the system, to make sure that we've balanced the interest of our customers with the interest of our shareholders.

And certainly, when you look at our mortgage rate, we've been either the lowest or the second lowest of all the major banks and the regionals through that period. And certainly we see the need to make sure that we do remain competitive in the marketplace. And certainly we've obviously got to manage our funding costs and our pricing, obviously on an ongoing basis.
So we will continue to monitor this situation, and we will make decisions in regard to what we have to do in regard to pricing as and when necessary.

As far as growth is concerned, I don't think there is any doubt that everybody around the country has experienced a degree of drop-off in activity during the last two to three months. And I think that our view is that the first half will be a little softer than possibly we thought coming into this year – that is, the calendar year. And I think that my view is that the second half will be stronger.

And if you look at the underlying performance of the Australian economy, you look at the situation regarding the trading surpluses that we are seeing coming through. There is no doubt that the Australian economy is, underlying, performing well.

I think that you'll see obviously a flow through into the economy from those higher levels of trading balance into the overall economy as far as further investment. But I think that that's probably going to be lighter in this half rather than earlier in this half, so that would give me some confidence that the second half would be stronger.
Second half calendar, was that?
Financial.
Financial. The second half.
Can I just add? I mean, obviously our target would be grow at or above system.
Craig?
Thanks. It's Craig Williams from Citi here. Your response to James's first question there, I think suggested that you are keeping an eye on your funding costs.

So do you think there is a need to control deposit pricing as an industry a bit more than has been the case, rather than necessarily the recovery of your retail and margins coming on the asset side of the balance sheet?

And a second question, with respect to the core banking system amortization in particular. Slide 41 and 40 sort of gives a bit of color there, but how much of the cost of this project are we seeing through the P&L over the next couple of years? And how much sort of really hits the P&L, once the project is largely built out and complete?
Okay. I will pass over to David to talk about the second part of your question first. Dave, in regard to the core banking system?
Well, it would be amortized over, I think, 10 – Michael? 10 years. And basically the amortization starts as different components within the system are turned on.

So very little has yet been turned on, so there is very little amortization. It will be I think 2013 would be the first year of full amortization. And then the last of that will be 10 years after that.
In regard to deposit pricing, well, deposit pricing is really a situation where the market prevails.

We certainly have, in the second half of the financial year, probably taken a more competitive stance than we took in the first half of the year. And the reason for that was that we did see some outflow of deposits. But if you look at our position today, we have increased our proportion of domestic funding versus wholesale funding to 58%.

And certainly, there's obviously been a lot of pressure from a number of financial institutions who have not been able to access wholesale money because of their ratings, which has led to a situation where they've obviously bid up the cost of deposits. And therefore we've had to go some way towards competing. So I don't think the ACCC would be very keen for me to make any comments about – and I wouldn't be keen to make any comments about what they should do in regard to the system.
Yeah, I think there is no doubt that deposit pricing is going to be an ongoing challenge.
Jarrod?
Jarrod Martin from Credit Suisse. First of all, a follow-up question to Victor's question, acknowledging you're taking the Bankwest provision below the line against the acquisition cost.

Why has it taken eighteen months? I thought this would have been done during due diligence, so why has it taken eighteen months to do that? I thought that was all part of the negotiation with HBOS. So that's first question.

As far as our business is concerned, what we've demonstrated I think over the last year or two as we've got our customer service proposition right is that our customers have been prepared to do much more business with us. As far as the management is concerned, the replicating portfolio and indeed the balance sheet positioning are both countercyclical things that are put in place to protect against low interest rate environments. So as when we were in the very low interest environment, and therefore by definition in the low interest rate environment, you tend to be in the middle of a downturn and normal interest income declines because you've got less, less interest rates.

You have this hedge protection in replicating portfolio to protect against that, and indeed we'd also taken balance sheet position to protect against low interest rates. So as interest rate go up, the value of that hedge declines, and what we're seeing here is that impact. So interest rates go up, less relative impact of replicating portfolio.
